REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS ,'. BONDS—STATE TRUST FUNDS The Trust Funds under this subdivision are those administered by the Board of Educational Lands and Funds which Board is composed of the Governor, Secretary of State, Attorney General, State Treasurer, and State Superintendent of Public Instruction. On pages ..- to .....',. of this Report, we show the total investments and cash in each of the various Trust Accounts. The total investment in Bonds in these various accounts, as of June 30, 1942, was $14,269,020.95 as compared to $13,785,366.35 on June 30, 1940 and $13,912,281.98 on June 30, 1938. No Tosses in these accounts were charged off during the period covered by this Biennial Report. A complete list of these investments, as of January 7, 1943, will be incorporated in our Semi- Annual Audit of the State Treasurer, which audit will be in your hands January 7, 1943. Not only will this audit give a complete list of all investments, but will also show in detail the status of each as of January 7,1943. [. The following is a copy of a resolution appearing in the minutes of a meeting of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds on February 27, 1942. :..: Moved by Walter R. Johnson, seconded by Charles W. Taylor that the Secretary of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds be directed to make a determination of the amount of loss that has been sustained by the Trust Fund Principal of the State of Nebraska, and that the assistance of the Btate Auditor be requested, insofar as it is deemed necessary to make ¦:, such report, -the report to be submitted to this Board on or before January 1, 1943, in order that it may in turn refer the report to the Legislature at their next regular session. Motion unanimously carried. This report made under the direction and supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts has been completed and delivered and covers a period from the year 1869 to June 30, 1939. In view of our findings in this Audit we respectfully refer you to Article 7, Sec. 9 of our Con - stitution which reads in part as follows: "All funds belonging to the state for educational purposes, the interest and income whereof only are to be used, shall be deemed trust funds held by the state, and the state shall supply all losses thereof, that may in any manner accrue, so that the same shall remain forever inviolate and undiminished; ............". Therefore, it is suggested that the Legislature make some provision for reimbursing the Permanent School Funds for any loss which may appear. : , v, / I would recommend that a similar audit and report be made of all of the Permanent Trust Funds to establish once and for all any loss whichmay have accrued since the inception of these funds. To do this will require some j financial assistance from- the Legislature. We are now making an ..audit and investigation of the Bessey Memorial Endowment Fund. Our complete report of this Fund will be in your hands before January 7, 1943. Our investigation has developed far enough at the time of the writing of this report to make us wonder who is responsible for the administration of the Bessey Memorial Endowment Fund. At present it appears as though the Board of Educational Lands and Funds were administering the account. As late as in August, 1941, the Board of Educational Lands and Funds invested $1,900 of these funds in Government Bonds. The State Treasurer, as a member of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds,

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS is custodian of all investments of this fund. However, we have found that early investments of the furid were made by the Board of Regents of the State University of Nebraska. I wish to refer to the Session Laws of the State of Nebraska, 1917, Chapter 239 (H. R. 496), Section 2, which is as follows: The Board of Regents of the University of Nebraska are hereby made and constituted the Bessey Memorial Fund Com - mission, with full power and authority to carry into effect the purposes of this act. The foregoing section of the law places full responsibility for the administration of this Act in the hands of the Board of Regents of the University of Nebraska, and this fund should be removed from its present status, which is under the Board of Educational Lands and Funds. *-»•«-» Referring again to the Session Laws of the State of Nebraska 1917, Chapter 239 (H. R. 496), Section 5 which, in part, reads as follows: Said commission shall from time to time invest and re - invest said fund, as weU as all unused increase or accumula - tions thereof and all additions to said fund which may here - after be made, in notes secured by first mortgages, at annual or semi-annual interest, on improved farm lands in the State of Nebraska, said lands in each case to be of the fair and actual cash value, exclusive of improvements thereon, of at least double the amount of such mortgage thereon. From this you will note the Commission can only invest in real estate mortgages. In view of present conditions would it not be advisable to redraft this bill to allow the Commission to invest in liquid marketable government securities? WARRANTS As the total receipts and expenditures have increased each'Bien - nium, so also are the number of warrants written by this office in - creased. The number of warrants written and the total amount In dollars of these warrants for the past Biennium and for this Biennium are as follows: Fiscal Year Ended Warrants Written Amount June 30, 1939 208,020 $35:748,513.93 June 30, 1940 196 ;_ 54 V57_;_97:75 Totals for the Biennium 404,474 $70,326,711.68 June 30, 1941 214,229 $37,800,087.07 June 30, 1942 204,460 . 38,257,266.24 Total for the Biennium 418.689 $76,057,353.31 Increase over last Biennium 14,215 $ 5,730,641.63 STATE TAX LEVY 1939 Valuation of the State for taxation purposes $2,047,519,59100 Levy of 2.41 mills 4,934,522.00 Redemption Fund Levy of 2/10 of 1 mill 409,503.92

REDEMPTION FUND LEVY * Under Section 77-1007, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska 1929, the State Board of Equalization is authorized to make a levy of two - tenths of one mill, or such part thereof as may be necessary in estab - lishing and maintaining a Redemption Fund. The Redemption Fund Tax collected is included with the total amount of General Fund Taxes as shown by each county under Statement ,5 of this report. INSANE TAX LEVY; Section 83-756, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska 1929, provides that the Superintendent of the State Hospitals shall certify to the Auditor of State quarterly the amount due to such hospital from the several counties having patients chargeable thereto. Statement No. 5-B of this report reflects status of the Insane Tax Fund as of June 30, 1942. The total amount of tax delinquent, $370,295.05. It Will be noted there is a slight decrease in the amount of delin - quent tax over the past Biennium. In view of the fact that percentage of tax collections all over the State are much larger than in previous years,, this amount;should continue to decrease. REGISTRATION OF BONDS During the Biennium from July 1, 1940 to June 30, 1942, the Auditor of Public Accounts examined the history and transcripts of proceedings and registered bonds of the various political subdivisions of the State in the aggregate amount of $14,158,750.15, as shown in statement No. 8. Of this amount, $7,315,425.94 were refunding bonds, $6,389,436.26 were original bonds, and $453,887.95 were funding bonds issued under L. B. No. 183 passed by the 1941 session of the Legislature. This Bui, or Act, and the benefits thereof will expire on December, 31, 1942. "¦:",';• '•':"'¦;¦ V Statement No: 9 shows the total outstanding debt on June 30, 1942 to be $73,954,411.08, this amount exclusive of Public Power, debt. In arriving at this figure we are dependent on the various political sub - divisions to notify us of any redemption or cancellation having been made. For comparison, the total outstanding debt on June 30, 1940 was $69,019,747.78, exclusive of Public Power debt. Since the instigation and expansion of the Pubic Power and Irriga - tion Districts, together with the Consumers Pubic Power District,,there

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS has accrued by these Districts a total outstanding bonded debt of $89 - 389,610.73, as of June 30, 1942. This total is set out in detail in state - ment No. 8-B. This is an increase of $47,961,001.16 over the total amount of Public Power debt outstanding June 30, 1940. The total bonded debt as set out in statement No. 9, plus the total set out in statement No. 8-B, brings the total State bonded debt to $163, - -344,021.81 as compared to $110,448,357.35 June 30, 1940. The credit rating of most of the political subdivisions of Nebraska - is reflected in the low interest rate the bonds carry which were regis - tered during this Biennium. Our bond records are much improved over previous years. We now have a card system reflecting the status of each issue and can give the total outstanding debt of each political subdivision at a minutes notice. The county clerks now report immediately to us any redemption or can - cellation of bonds in their respective counties. COUNTY BUDGET The County Budget Act of 1937, as amended in 1939, applies to all counties and provides for the uniform procedure necessary in the com - putation and preparation ot an annual budget for each office depart - ment or activity. ; The budget shall show all proposed expenditures from funds appro - priated for the administration, operation and maintenance of all offices and departments, the anticipated income from all sources, including taxes to be levied, fees, licenses, and all other means of financing the proposed expenditures for the current year. There has been assistance given by this office to the counties in preparing the budget and there is need for further direction and for monthly, or at least quarterly, supervision as to the operation during the year. If provision could be made for the necessary supervision, the proper functions of the Act could, and would, be accomplished and the counties, and the State as a whole, would profit from more accurate budget operations. Some of the deviations that have been corrected are, toe proper distribution of the delinquent tax sinking fund money, the elimination of transferring funds, unnecessary padding of estimated requirements, the discontinuance of contracts or agreements for a longer period than the budget year, the uniform summary publication, and many other irregularities. Fuum_.i__n, To facilitate the budget work, and to establish a more accurate procedure, some legislative changes are recommended. Under the pres - ent law, the budget is made as of Nevember Ist of each year and the levy made the following August. If the county fiscal year was changed to end on June 30th, and the budget made as of July Ist, with only one weekly publication Instead of three, the levy could be made within thirty days after the budget was made and the April Ist valuation would also be available as well as the complete year's income and ex - penditures. Further, more important we would have available the actual cash balances remaining in each fund as of June 30th as shown by the county treasurer's closing balances instead of as now we must anticipate the balance m each fund. To increase greater efficiency and economy a provision should be made to include all political subdivisions in the county budget program under the direction and supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS UNIFORM ACCOUNTING ' The establishment of a uniform system of accounting for all county offices is provided under Section 26-1312, 1941 Compiled Supplement of Nebraska and has as its basic objective; economy in the purchase of supplies, simplicity of forms, and accuracy in record keeping. Each county officer is functioning under the same governing law and therefore the record forms should be identical in each county. A complete uniform system has been approved and installed by the Audi - tor of Public Accounts in a great many of the offices of the various counties and is now operating with very satisfactory results. On page 10 is reproduced a sheet of the cash and fee book, which our State Examiners found to be in use in the office ot a county judge in one of our counties. As evidence of our work in installing better, and uniform system of accounting, on page 11 is the reproduction of the approved system installed by the Auditor of Public Accounts in the same office replacing the type of accounting and record keeping aa shown on page 10. REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS EXAMINATION OF COUNTY RECORDS. Section 26-1309, 1939 Compiled Supplement, provides fbr a com - plete and comprehensive audit of all books, records and accounts of the offices of the various counties in the state, under the direction and supervision of the Auditor of Public Accounts. Detailed examinations have been made in all counties and a com - plete comprehensive report made, delivered, .and on file in the county clerk's office in each county. In addition to the regular examinations, several special audits were made of officers upon request of the Attor - ney General, Grand Jury, or county boards, or when we deemed neces - sary. These audits are made without any cost to the counties and re - lieves them of the expense of private audits and gives them a more complete and detailed examination, together with a uniform, coopera - tive and constructive program throughout the state. Assistance and counsel is available at all times to any of the county officers from the Auditor of Public Accounts and his staff. The value of these thorough and efficient examinations of all county offices is evidenced by the recovery of unremitted fees, clerical errors and embezzled accounts amounting to approximately $92,000.00 which has |ieen paid back into the various funds of the counties. There should be muted interest in a unified program for better county government, carefully managed, capably supervised, and an - nually audited. With provisions for sufficient personnel the Auditor of Public Accounts can conduct the examination of all county offices on an annual basis, which would be an asset to all county officials and create an atmosphere of confidence and security with the taxpayers In each and every county. SEMI-ANNUAL AUDIT OF STATE TREASURER. For some years previous to 1939, semi-annual audits of the State Treasurer were made by others than the Auditor of Public Accounts of the State. Since January 5, 1939, complete and detailed audits have been made of the State Treasurer's office on July Ist and January Ist of each year by the Auditor of Public Accounts. We also incorporate in these audits a complete and detailed report of all the permanent and temporary school funds, of which the State Treasurer is custodian. A copy of each of these semi-annual audits has been delivered to the Gov - ernor of the State. In 1941 the Legislature set up a revolving fund of $400,000.00, to be charged against the General Fund, for the use in supplying funds for the Food Stamp Plan. Up to date, there has only been $150,000 of this fund used at any one time. In all probability from now on the use of this fund will decrease, so it is evident that this revolving fund set up by the next Appropriations Committee need not be in excess of $150. - -000.00 :¦¦¦¦¦¦ AUDITING "OF STATE OFFICES, COMMISSIONS, INSTITUTIONS AND NORMAL SCHOOLS. During the Biennium covered by this report, I wish to advise you that we have made audits of the following state offices, commissions, and institutions: Nebraska Liquor Control Commission; Game, Fores - tatton and Parks Conunission; American Legion State Fund Relief Com - mittee; Clerk of the Supreme Court; Metropolitan Utilities District,

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Omaha;; Nebraska State Racing Commission; Institute of Feeble Minded, Beatrice; Secretary of State; and Superintendent of Public In - struction. We have also audited the books and records of the Board of Educational Lands and Funds; State Board of Agriculture (known as the State Fair Board); Division of Athletics; Office of the Adjutant General; Department of Health; Nebraska State Penitentiary; Ne - braska Prison Industries; and the office of the State Tax Commis - sioner;-'-.; . ':;' '-.' In addition to the above, an annual audit has been made of the four State Normal Schools located at Chadron, Peru, Wayne, and Kearney. As these four schools are operating under one Board under the same laws, and having identical activities, through the fine co - operation of the Board and the officers of the various Schools, we have been able to make great headway on a uniform system of accounting and a uniform system of records in the four Schools. Due to the lack of personnel and appropriations, most of the penal institutions, and the larger State Departments, such as the Department of Agriculture; Highway Department; Board of Control; and the Rail - way Commission, all of which handle cash accounts, have not been audited for several years by the Auditor of Public Accounts. ¦ '¦'' '¦.:.;¦;/:.:. :'¦"¦::' finis. '".;¦' We have followed to the letter the instructions of the previous Legislature with reference to the Appropriation Bill. All vouchers pre - sented to us have been carefully checked and those not meeting statu - tory requirements were rejected. All warrants issued in payment of these vouchers have been charged to the proper funds or accounts in strict accordance with the Appropriations Bill. An appropriation is not an actual expenditure, but solely an au - thority given to officials to create legal obligations up to certain amounts for a, specific purpose. The offices of Auditor of Public Accounts and State Treasurer are so constructed by practical application and by statutory law, as to be a check upon one another. No money can be paid out of the State Treasury except upon the Auditor's warrant and all Warrants issued by the Auditor must be paid by the Treasurer. The accounts of these two offices must balance at the end of each month and no error could develop in these balances without the knowledge of both the State Audi - tor and the State Treasurer. On page 16 of this report we have reproduced a map of the State of Nebraska dividing the State by counties into eight districts. Under the present law we are entitled to eight examiners. By placing one examiner in each of these eight districts, we would be able to, more efficiently, economically, and effectively, meet the requirements of the present laws governing this office. In particular the County Auditing Law, the supervision of the Budget Law, and the Uniform Accounting Law. In view of the present conditions, particularly with reference to travel, we would be able to reach all parts of the State at much less expense and could eliminate the use of private automobiles to a great degree, as -dost of the counties are available from these key points by bus of train. A plan similar to this was presented to the State Legislature of 1939, and we stressed the importance of this at that time. Thit program would not function unless it is pos - sible to have an assistant examiner work with each of our eight ex - aminers at these points.

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS We have made several recommendations concerning certain laws and administrative practices of the State in the hope that the State's affairs may be administered more efficiently. ' CONCLUSION. This report would be incomplete had I failed to express my keen appreciation of the cordiality and kindness always accorded me by your Excellency. It has been a constant source of satisfaction to feel that I enjoyed the respect and friendship of you and all.other Execu - tive officials of the State, individually and collectively. I have always been happy to regard it as an essential part of my duties to furnish such officials, whenever requested, information regarding the fiscal affairs of the State. To my fellow office workers, I express my sincere appreciation of their splendid loyalty and efficiency. Respectfully Submitted, RAY C. JOHNSON, Audior of Public Accounts.
